function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Lack of adequate ventilation in home isolation spaces can lead to increased risk of virus spread within the household.","Impact":"Higher likelihood of transmission and infection within the household, leading to increased community spread of the virus.","Mitigation":"Improving ventilation in home isolation spaces and using designated, adequately ventilated rooms for isolation.","Technologies":"Ventilation systems, air purifiers, and monitoring devices for air quality.","People":"People living with mild COVID-19 symptoms who are advised to isolate at home, especially those living in shared household spaces.","Owner":"Local health authorities, homeowners, and housing associations."},{"Description":"Sharing of communal spaces, such as toilets, in households where individuals are advised to isolate at home can increase the risk of virus transmission among family members.","Impact":"Higher likelihood of intra-household transmission and infection, leading to increased community spread of the virus.","Mitigation":"Implementing measures to minimize contact and sharing of communal spaces, such as using dedicated toilets and disinfection protocols.","Technologies":"Smart PPE, 3D-printed isolation wards, and ecological toilet systems.","People":"People living with mild COVID-19 symptoms who are advised to isolate at home, and their family members.","Owner":"Homeowners, local health authorities, and companies providing innovative solutions for home isolation."},{"Description":"Inadequate protective equipment for health care workers can increase the risk of infection while interacting with COVID-19 patients.","Impact":"Higher risk of infection among health care workers, leading to potential shortage of medical staff and compromised patient care.","Mitigation":"Improving the design and functionality of personal protective equipment (PPE) to enhance safety and reduce transmission risk.","Technologies":"Smart PPE, 3D-printed isolation wards, and advanced PPE manufacturing techniques.","People":"Health care workers who come into contact with COVID-19 patients.","Owner":"Health care facilities, PPE manufacturers, and regulatory bodies overseeing PPE standards."}]}
